The 1-[skeleton](/wiki/Skeleton_\(topology\) "Skeleton \(topology\)") of
pyramid is a [wheel graph](/wiki/Wheel_graph "Wheel graph")

In [geometry](/wiki/Geometry "Geometry"), a **pyramid** is a
[polyhedron](/wiki/Polyhedron "Polyhedron") formed by connecting a
[polygonal](/wiki/Polygon "Polygon") base and a point, called the
[apex](/wiki/Apex_\(geometry\) "Apex \(geometry\)"). Each base edge and apex
form a triangle, called a _lateral face_. It is a [conic solid](/wiki/Cone
"Cone") with polygonal base. A pyramid with an _n_ -sided base has _n_ \+ 1
vertices, _n_ \+ 1 faces, and 2 _n_ edges. All pyramids are [self-
dual](/wiki/Self-dual_polyhedron "Self-dual polyhedron").

A **right pyramid** has its apex directly above the [centroid](/wiki/Centroid
"Centroid") of its base. Nonright pyramids are called **oblique pyramids**. A
**regular pyramid** has a [regular polygon](/wiki/Regular_polygon "Regular
polygon") base and is usually implied to be a _right pyramid_.[1][2]

When unspecified, a pyramid is usually assumed to be a _regular_ [square
pyramid](/wiki/Square_pyramid "Square pyramid"), like the physical
[pyramid](/wiki/Pyramid "Pyramid") structures. A [triangle](/wiki/Triangle
"Triangle")-based pyramid is more often called a
[tetrahedron](/wiki/Tetrahedron "Tetrahedron").

Among oblique pyramids, like [acute and obtuse
triangles](/wiki/Acute_and_obtuse_triangles "Acute and obtuse triangles"), a
pyramid can be called _acute_ if its apex is above the interior of the base
and _obtuse_ if its apex is above the exterior of the base. A **right-angled
pyramid** has its apex above an edge or vertex of the base. In a tetrahedron
these qualifiers change based on which face is considered the base.

Pyramids are a subclass of the [prismatoids](/wiki/Prismatoid "Prismatoid").
Pyramids can be doubled into [bipyramids](/wiki/Bipyramid "Bipyramid") by
adding a second offset point on the other side of the base plane.

## Right pyramids with a regular
base[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pyramid_\(geometry\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Right pyramids with a regular base")]

A right pyramid with a regular base has isosceles triangle sides, with
symmetry is C _n_ v or [1,_n_], with order 2 _n_. It can be given an extended
[Schläfli symbol](/wiki/Schl%C3%A4fli_symbol "Schläfli symbol") ( ) ∨ {_n_},
representing a point, ( ), joined (orthogonally offset) to a [regular
polygon](/wiki/Regular_polygon "Regular polygon"), {n}. A join operation
creates a new edge between all pairs of vertices of the two joined figures.

The **trigonal** or **triangular pyramid** with all [equilateral
triangles](/wiki/Equilateral_triangle "Equilateral triangle") faces becomes
the [regular](/wiki/Regular_polyhedron "Regular polyhedron")
[tetrahedron](/wiki/Tetrahedron "Tetrahedron"), one of the [Platonic
solids](/wiki/Platonic_solid "Platonic solid"). A lower symmetry case of the
**triangular pyramid** is C3v, which has an equilateral triangle base, and 3
identical isosceles triangle sides. The square and pentagonal pyramids can
also be composed of regular convex polygons, in which case they are [Johnson
solids](/wiki/Johnson_solid "Johnson solid").

If all edges of a square pyramid (or any convex polyhedron) are
[tangent](/wiki/Tangent "Tangent") to a [sphere](/wiki/Sphere "Sphere") so
that the average position of the tangential points are at the center of the
sphere, then the pyramid is said to be
[canonical](/wiki/Dual_polyhedron#Canonical_duals "Dual polyhedron"), and it
forms half of a regular [octahedron](/wiki/Octahedron "Octahedron").

Pyramids with a hexagonal or higher base must be composed of isosceles
triangles; a hexagonal pyramid with equilateral triangles would be a
completely flat figure, and a heptagonal or higher would have the triangles
not meet at all.

### Right Star
pyramids[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pyramid_\(geometry\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Right Star pyramids")]

Right pyramids with [regular star polygon](/wiki/Regular_star_polygon "Regular
star polygon") bases are called **star pyramids**.[3] For example, the
pentagrammic pyramid has a [pentagram](/wiki/Pentagram "Pentagram") base and 5
intersecting triangle sides.

    [![Pentagram pyramid.png](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Pentagram_pyramid.png/120px-Pentagram_pyramid.png)](/wiki/File:Pentagram_pyramid.png)

## Volume[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pyramid_\(geometry\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Volume")]

See also: [Cone (geometry) – Volume](/wiki/Cone_\(geometry\)#Volume "Cone
\(geometry\)")

The [volume](/wiki/Volume "Volume") of a pyramid (also any cone) is  V = 1 3 b
h {\displaystyle V={\tfrac {1}{3}}bh} ![{\\displaystyle V={\\tfrac
{1}{3}}bh}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e1a5847f5f00b07da3b82f4baef764a362c6140d),
where _b_ is the [area](/wiki/Area "Area") of the base and _h_ the height from
the base to the apex. This works for any polygon, regular or non-regular, and
any location of the apex, provided that _h_ is measured as the
[perpendicular](/wiki/Perpendicular "Perpendicular") distance from the
[plane](/wiki/Plane_\(geometry\) "Plane \(geometry\)") containing the base. In
499 AD [Aryabhata](/wiki/Aryabhata "Aryabhata"), a
[mathematician](/wiki/Mathematician
"Mathematician")-[astronomer](/wiki/Astronomer "Astronomer") from the
classical age of [Indian mathematics](/wiki/Indian_mathematics "Indian
mathematics") and [Indian astronomy](/wiki/Indian_astronomy "Indian
astronomy"), used this method in the _[Aryabhatiya](/wiki/Aryabhatiya
"Aryabhatiya")_ (section 2.6).

The formula can be formally proved using calculus. By similarity, the _linear_
dimensions of a cross-section parallel to the base increase linearly from the
apex to the base. The scaling factor (proportionality factor) is  1 − y h
{\displaystyle 1-{\tfrac {y}{h}}} ![{\\displaystyle 1-{\\tfrac
{y}{h}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/02d2cda3d4f10f8426d643bab895505202d5d7e3),
or  h − y h {\displaystyle {\tfrac {h-y}{h}}} ![{\\displaystyle {\\tfrac
{h-y}{h}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/dcff0c7947a7123356641601ba308e26b33dd30b),
where _h_ is the height and _y_ is the perpendicular distance from the plane
of the base to the cross-section. Since the [area](/wiki/Area "Area") of any
cross-section is proportional to the square of the shape's
[scaling](/wiki/Scaling_\(geometry\) "Scaling \(geometry\)") factor, the area
of a cross-section at height _y_ is  b ( h − y ) 2 h 2 {\displaystyle b{\tfrac
{(h-y)^{2}}{h^{2}}}} ![{\\displaystyle b{\\tfrac
{\(h-y\)^{2}}{h^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b8975953d9eb0bf9ad15e930e2356469672ee64f),
or since both _b_ and _h_ are constants,  b h 2 ( h − y ) 2 {\displaystyle
{\tfrac {b}{h^{2}}}(h-y)^{2}} ![{\\displaystyle {\\tfrac
{b}{h^{2}}}\(h-y\)^{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1f62ce428b158894db1fc9e84a53521bb9e6a4f3).
The volume is given by the integral

     b h 2 ∫ 0 h ( h − y ) 2 d y = − b 3 h 2 ( h − y ) 3 | 0 h = 1 3 b h . {\displaystyle {\frac {b}{h^{2}}}\int _{0}^{h}(h-y)^{2}\,dy={\frac {-b}{3h^{2}}}(h-y)^{3}{\bigg |}_{0}^{h}={\tfrac {1}{3}}bh.} ![{\\frac  {b}{h^{2}}}\\int _{0}^{h}\(h-y\)^{2}\\,dy={\\frac  {-b}{3h^{2}}}\(h-y\)^{3}{\\bigg |}_{0}^{h}={\\tfrac  {1}{3}}bh.](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/edc9cc4d15f6189b6a3ea35d91de3d07231d083e)

The same equation,  V = 1 3 b h {\displaystyle V={\tfrac {1}{3}}bh}
![{\\displaystyle V={\\tfrac
{1}{3}}bh}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e1a5847f5f00b07da3b82f4baef764a362c6140d),
also holds for cones with any base. This can be proven by an argument similar
to the one above; see [volume of a cone](/wiki/Cone_\(geometry\)#Volume "Cone
\(geometry\)").

For example, the volume of a pyramid whose base is an _n_ -sided [regular
polygon](/wiki/Regular_polygon "Regular polygon") with side length _s_ and
whose height is _h_ is

     V = n 12 h s 2 cot ⁡ π n . {\displaystyle V={\frac {n}{12}}hs^{2}\cot {\frac {\pi }{n}}.} ![V={\\frac  {n}{12}}hs^{2}\\cot {\\frac  {\\pi }{n}}.](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ef6a55fde5a4105d418a8d1dae1fad22c59cc4cb)

The formula can also be derived exactly without calculus for pyramids with
rectangular bases. Consider a unit cube. Draw lines from the center of the
cube to each of the 8 vertices. This partitions the cube into 6 equal square
pyramids of base area 1 and height 1/2. Each pyramid clearly has volume of
1/6. From this we deduce that pyramid volume = height × base area / 3.

Next, expand the cube uniformly in three directions by unequal amounts so that
the resulting rectangular solid edges are _a_ , _b_ and _c_ , with solid
volume _abc_. Each of the 6 pyramids within are likewise expanded. And each
pyramid has the same volume _abc_ /6. Since pairs of pyramids have heights _a_
/2, _b_ /2 and _c_ /2, we see that pyramid volume = height × base area / 3
again.

When the side triangles are equilateral, the formula for the volume is

     V = 1 12 n s 3 cot ⁡ ( π n ) 1 − 1 4 sin 2 ⁡ π n . {\displaystyle V={\frac {1}{12}}ns^{3}\cot \left({\frac {\pi }{n}}\right){\sqrt {1-{\frac {1}{4\sin ^{2}{\tfrac {\pi }{n}}}}}}.} ![{\\displaystyle V={\\frac {1}{12}}ns^{3}\\cot \\left\({\\frac {\\pi }{n}}\\right\){\\sqrt {1-{\\frac {1}{4\\sin ^{2}{\\tfrac {\\pi }{n}}}}}}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9d9c2de89ada28df32fd4648acccfec1a06f08e2)

This formula only applies for _n_ = 2, 3, 4 and 5; and it also covers the case
_n_ = 6, for which the volume equals zero (i.e., the pyramid height is
zero).[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

## Surface
area[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pyramid_\(geometry\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Surface area")]

The [surface area](/wiki/Surface_area "Surface area") of a pyramid is  A = B +
P L 2 {\displaystyle A=B+{\tfrac {PL}{2}}} ![{\\displaystyle A=B+{\\tfrac
{PL}{2}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fcc278734ac4d609bb979e061d6def1dc641b329),
where _B_ is the base area, _P_ is the base [perimeter](/wiki/Perimeter
"Perimeter"), and the [slant height](/wiki/Slant_height "Slant height") L = h
2 + r 2 {\displaystyle L={\sqrt {h^{2}+r^{2}}}} ![{\\displaystyle L={\\sqrt
{h^{2}+r^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0c88df03580c3f0115bc7ca36af82dd92d9291a1),
where _h_ is the pyramid altitude and _r_ is the [inradius](/wiki/Inradius
"Inradius") of the base.

## n-dimensional
pyramids[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pyramid_\(geometry\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: n-dimensional pyramids")]

A 2-dimensional pyramid is a triangle, formed by a base edge connected to a
noncolinear point called an [apex](/wiki/Apex_\(geometry\) "Apex
\(geometry\)").

A 4-dimensional pyramid is called a [polyhedral
pyramid](/wiki/Polyhedral_pyramid "Polyhedral pyramid"), constructed by a
[polyhedron](/wiki/Polyhedron "Polyhedron") in a 3-space hyperplane of 4-space
with another point off that hyperplane.

Higher-dimensional pyramids are constructed similarly.

The family of [simplices](/wiki/Simplex "Simplex") represent pyramids in any
dimension, increasing from [triangle](/wiki/Triangle "Triangle"),
[tetrahedron](/wiki/Tetrahedron "Tetrahedron"), [5-cell](/wiki/5-cell
"5-cell"), [5-simplex](/wiki/5-simplex "5-simplex"), etc. A n-dimensional
simplex has the minimum _n+1_ [vertices](/wiki/Vertex_\(geometry\) "Vertex
\(geometry\)"), with all pairs of vertices connected by
[edges](/wiki/Edge_\(geometry\) "Edge \(geometry\)"), all triples of vertices
defining faces, all quadruples of points defining tetrahedral
[cells](/wiki/Cell_\(geometry\) "Cell \(geometry\)"), etc.

### Polyhedral
pyramid[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pyramid_\(geometry\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Polyhedral pyramid")]

In 4-dimensional [geometry](/wiki/Geometry "Geometry"), a **polyhedral
pyramid** is a [4-polytope](/wiki/4-polytope "4-polytope") constructed by a
base [polyhedron](/wiki/Polyhedron "Polyhedron") cell and an
[apex](/wiki/Apex_\(geometry\) "Apex \(geometry\)") point. The lateral
[facets](/wiki/Facet_\(geometry\) "Facet \(geometry\)") are pyramid cells,
each constructed by one face of the base polyhedron and the apex. The vertices
and edges of polyhedral pyramids form examples of [apex
graphs](/wiki/Apex_graph "Apex graph"), graphs formed by adding one vertex
(the apex) to a [planar graph](/wiki/Planar_graph "Planar graph") (the graph
of the base).

The regular [5-cell](/wiki/5-cell "5-cell") (or 4-[simplex](/wiki/Simplex
"Simplex")) is an example of a _tetrahedral pyramid_. Uniform polyhedra with
circumradii less than 1 can be make polyhedral pyramids with regular
tetrahedral sides. A polyhedron with _v_ vertices, _e_ edges, and _f_ faces
can be the base on a polyhedral pyramid with _v+1_ vertices, _e+v_ edges,
_f+e_ faces, and _1+f_ cells.

A 4D _polyhedral pyramid_ with axial symmetry can be visualized in 3D with a
[Schlegel diagram](/wiki/Schlegel_diagram "Schlegel diagram")—a 3D projection
that places the apex at the center of the base polyhedron.

Any convex 4-polytope can be divided into **polyhedral pyramids** by adding an
interior point and creating one pyramid from each facet to the center point.
This can be useful for computing volumes.

The 4-dimensional _volume_ of a polyhedral pyramid is 1/4 of the volume of the
base polyhedron times its perpendicular height, compared to the area of a
triangle being 1/2 the length of the base times the height and the volume of a
pyramid being 1/3 the area of the base times the height.
